Award.AwardTitle: Linkages between soil and food quality in traditional plant systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the research efforts of faculty at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will inform the body of knowledge about issues of biological significance. The proposed research focuses on the production of culturally relevant berry and root crops on agricultural land within a coastal marine ecosystem. The goals are to: 1) establish and cultivate traditional berry and roots crops on tribally owned land and link food quality to soil quality; and 2) increase faculty research capacity and engage tribal college students in soil ecology, plant biology, and ethnobiology. The connection of faculty to research and thereby the students to culturally and geographically relevant research is an important step in retaining students who are more likely to pursue advanced degrees.

The faculty research project tests hypotheses that state a) increased biological diversity increases the level of phytonutrients in perrenial and annual traditional plants, and b) low input, organic nitrogen applications will increase biological diversity and the percentage of organic matter in soil, and reduce the amount of nitrate activity in plant tissue. A cultivation system of traditional plants will be established with fertility treatments applied and assessed over a two-year period. Plant tissue will be examined for survival and growth, phytonutrients and nitrate activity, and yield. Additionally, soil quality, biologic activity, and biodiversity metagenomic analysis will be performed. The PI will collaborate with partners at the Northwest Indian College Institute for Indigenous Foods and Traditions and the Swinomish Tribal Community, as well as advisors at the University of Victoria, USDA-ARS Horticultural Unit, and the Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation Department of Science, Engineering, and Energy. This project will provide: 1) a venue for demonstrating and investigating regionally significant best management practices (BMPs) for soil management and restoration; 2) new methods for quantifying the nutritional value and physiological response of traditional plants; and 3) culturally relevant research and education opportunities for faculty and students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had two main outcomes:

1) Establish and cultivate traditional berry crops on tribally-owned land and link food quality to soil quality.

2) Increase faculty research capacity and engage at least 30 Swinomish site students in soil ecology, plant biology, and ethnobiology.

This research project supported a culturally based approach to science. In so doing, it increased Indigenous students’ participation in scientific inquiry and research that supports their cultural background. The project engaged faculty, students, and community members in the project and left a legacy of a Native Plants demonstration garden – the 13 Moons Garden Project - that is used for classroom activities at all-levels of curriculum at the site.  In addition, the 13 Moons Garden is a common meeting place for community members, students, and faculty who work together to promote an inter-generational transfer of knowledge regarding traditional uses of plants.

Over the course of the grant period, this project engaged more than 60 Indigenous undergraduate students in the project, supported three undergraduate students in their Senior Capstone projects, and supported one post-baccalaureate research position.  The project also supported professional development of both faculty and students at Northwest Indian College, with participation at local, regional, and national scientific conferences.  Students presented their work at a diverse range of academic and community venues, including the American Geophysical Union, American Indian Science and Engineering Society (AISES) Conference, National Conferences American Indian Higher Education Consortium Conference, The Honoring Sacred Food: Wisdom for Seven Generations Summit, Seeds of Native Health Conference, The First Tribal / Urban Indian Food Sovereignty Summit, and the Billy Frank, Jr. Annual Salmon Summit.

The project also supported the development of an upper-division Food Sovereignty course, which engages with topics related to Native plants and environmental and social justice of tribal lands.  This class continues to be refined to reflect the place-based curriculum at the college.  This project further deepened the Native Environmental Science curriculum with the development of place-based curriculum and field excursions related to Native plants and soils.
